title-group.article-title: Social identity in Renaissance Venice: the second Serrata

permissions.copyright-statement: © 1994 The Society for Renaissance Studies and Oxford University Press

p.mixed-citation: P. J. Jones, 'Communes and despots: the city-state in late-medieval Italy', T Roy Hist, 5th ser., 15 (1965), 71-96. An early version of this paper was read as the Eric Cochrane Lecture in Renaissance History at the University of Chicago in April 1992; I would like to thank Lydia G. Cochrane and Julius Kirshner for the honour of this invitation.

The most authoritative modern studies of the Serrata, with discussion of the historiographie tradition, are Frederic C. Lane, 'The enlargement of the Great Council of Venice', in Florilegium Historiale: Essays Presented to Wallace K. Ferguson, ed. J. G. Rowe and W. H. Stockdale (Toronto, 1971), 236-74; and Gerhard Rösch, Der venezianische Adel bis zur Schliessung des Grossen Rats. Zur Genese einer Führungsschicht (Sigmaringen, 1989), ch. 6, 'Die sogenannte Serrata des Maggior Con- siglio vom Jahre 1297'. See also Margarete Merores, 'Der grosse Rat von Venedig und die sogenannte Serrata vom Jahre 1297', Vierteljahrschrift für Sozial- und Wirtschaftsgeschichte, 21 (1928), 33-113; and Giorgio Cracco, Società e stato nel medioevo veneziano (Florence, 1967), 211-350.

For recent statements of this view, see Guido Ruggiero, 'Modernization and the mythic state in early Renaissance Venice: the Serrata revisited', Viator, 10 (1979), 245-56; and Reinhold C. Mueller, 'Espressioni di status sociale a Venezia dopo la "Serrata" del Maggior Consiglio', in Studi veneti offerti a Gaetano Cozzi (Venice, 1992), 53-61.
James S. Grubb, 'When myths lose power: four decades of Venetian historiography', J Mod Hist, 58 (1986), 43-94.

The exceptions are John Easton Law, 'Age qualification and the Venetian constitution: the case of the Capello family', Pap Brit Sch Rome, 39 (1971), 125-37; and Élizabeth Crouzet Pavan, 'Sopra le acque salse: espaces, pouvoir et société à Venise à la fin du moyen âge Collection de l'Ecole Française de Rome, 156 (2 vols, Rome, 1992), i, 383-6.

An earlier analysis, stopping short of the Quattrocento, can be found in Stanley Chojnacki, 'In search of the Venetian patriciate: families and factions in the fourteenth century', in Renaissance Venice, ed. J. R. Hale (London, 1973), 47-90. A critical review of that article is in Ruggiero, 'Modernization and the mythic state'. Ruggiero's discussion does not assess the composition of the ruling class either before or after the Serrata, nor does it consider the reconstruction of the class in Merores, 'Der grosse Rat'. The corrective refinement of Merores's reconstruction in Rösch, Der venezianische Adel, was published after Ruggiero's article.

On identity as discussed here, see Anthony Giddens, Central Problems in Social Theory: Action, Structure and Contradiction in Social Analysis (Berkeley and Los Angeles, 1979); Anne Nor- ton, Reflections on Political Identity (Baltimore, Md, 1988); Paul Ricoeur, Oneself as Another, trans. Kathleen Blarney (Chicago, 1992); and Charles Taylor, Sources of the Self: The Making of the Modern Identity (Cambridge, Mass., 1989).

For formulations of this principle, see Norton, Reflections on Political Identity, 46; and Joan W. Scott, '"Experience"', in Feminists Theorize the Political, ed. Judith Butler and Joan W. Scott (New York, 1992), 22-40, at p. 34.

Claudio Donati, L'idea dinobiltà in Italia. Secoli XIV-XVIII {Bari and Rome, 1988). See also Paola Lanaro Sartori, Un'oligarchia urbana nel Cinquecento veneto: istituzioni, economia, società (Turin, 1992), 1-7, 21-4; Marino Berengo, 'Patriziato e nobiltà: il caso Veronese', in Potere e società negli stati regionali italiani fra '500 e '600, ed. Elena Fasano Guarini (Bologna, 1978), 191-213. A recent anthology of humanist writings on nobility is Albert Rabil, Jr (ed. and trans.), Knowledge, Goodnness, and Power: The Debate over Nobility among Quattrocento Italian Humanists, (Binghamton, N.Y., 1991).
Donati, L'idea dinobiltà, 10—12ff; esp. p. 20 n. 12.

Salutati's De nobilitate legum et medicine embodies an idea of hereditary nobility based on a family's history of 'fama, gloria, potentia, dignitatibus, divitiis et clientelis' ('reputation, glory, power, offices, wealth and clientele'), quoted in Donati, L'idea dinobiltà, 10.

Donati's illustration of this hierarchy is based on a discussion of the De imperatore militum diligendo (after 1453) by the Veronese jurist Bartolomeo Cipolla. Cipolla explicitly argued that the dignity conveyed by appointment as a condottiere by the Venetian Senate exceeded that deriving from (feudal) noble descent. See L'idea dinobiltà, 14-15.

The act is in Archivio di Stato di Venezia ( = ASV), Maggior Consiglio, Reg. 21, 'Leona', fols. 241v-242r (18 March 1414). On the Barbarella, see Stanley Chojnacki, 'Kinship ties and young patri- cians in fifteenth-century Venice', Renaiss Q, 38 (1985), 240-70; idem, 'Political adulthood in fifteenth-century Venice', Am Hist R, 19 (1986), 791-810.

An act of the Greater Council on 28 December 1376 forbidding membership to illegitimate sons of nobles had asserted that the presence of such men in the government might 'denigrare honorem et famam nostri dominii' ('besmirch the honour and reputation of our state'); ASV, Maggior Consiglio, Reg. 19, 'Novella', fol. 17lv.

For the view that notions of impurity in different cultures are rooted in a sense of the danger of things out of place, especially in moments of transition, see Mary Douglas, Purity and Danger: An Analysis of the Concepts of Pollution and Taboo (London and Boston, Mass., 1966), esp. pp. 114-28.

The ledger's collocation is ASV, Avogaria di Comun, 'Balla d'Oro', Reg. 162. In their studies of the Serrata, Lane and Rösch state that lists of applicants for admission to the Greater Council man- dated in a law of 1315 constituted rosters of the nobility, and as such were forerunners of the Libri d'Oro begun in 1506. Crouzet Pavan, following the older interpretation of Maranini, makes a similar statement. However, the requirement of the 1315 law, which is reproduced verbatim by Rösch, ap- plied not to men actually admitted to the Greater Council but only to applicants; its purpose was to provide the electors, who in 1315 still chose Council members, with a record of each year's self- nominees to which they could refer during their secret deliberations. The lists, which have not sur- vived, therefore did not constitute a record of the nobility's membership but only of men who aspired to it. See Rösch, Der venezianische Adel, 178-9; Lane, 'The enlargement of the Great Council', 258; Crouzet Pavan, Espaces, pouvoir et société, I, 385, with reference to Giuseppe Maranini, La costitu- zione de Venezia (2 vols., 1927-31; repr. Florence, 1974), II, 35.

These 164 families registered sons for the Barbarella either in Avogaria di Comun, 'Balla d'Oro', Reg. 162, which covers the years 1408-35, or in the subsequent registers 163, 164 or 165, which cover the rest of the century; or they appear as noble in other official records of government activity; ASV, Segretario alle Voci, 'Universi', serie antica, Regs. 4 and 6; and ASV, Avogaria di Comun, 'Prove di Eta', Regs. 177, 178. The total of 164 includes 163 houses allocated space in Register 162 plus the Lombardo, who are not included in Reg. 162 but are elsewhere documented as noble in the Quattrocento and had served in government office during the Trecento; see Chojnacki, 'In search of the Venetian patriciate', 47-90, at pp. 72 and 84 n. 60. One source indicates that in 1491 the Lombardo merged with the Lambardo, who were included in Avogaria di Comun, 'Balla d'Oro', Reg. 162; Biblioteca Marciana, Venice, It. vu 186 (7654), fol. 34v

The well-known proposal of 1403 to ennoble a new cittadino family for each noble family that died out indicates an awareness of extinctions. Its failure, however, indicates also the prevailing con- viction that replenishment was unnecessary or, more likely, undesirable. In any case, there is no evidence that the officials of the Collegio, where the proposal was debated and defeated, possessed a tally of the patriciate's membership. The debate is in ASV, Collegio, 'Notatorio', Reg. 3, fol. 11 lv (24 October 1403).

The main sources for extinction dates of noble families are lists compiled in the late Quattro- cento by Marino Sanudo in his Le vite dei dogi, ed. Giovanni Monticolo, in Rerum Italicarum Scrip- tores, new edn, vol. 22, pt 4 (Città di Castello, 1900); and the chronicle literature on the nobility in the Biblioteca Marciana. Examples of houses long extinct that appear in the avogadoris register are the Aicardo, reportedly extinct in 1353 or 1365; the Briosso, reportedly even before the Serrata, either in 1280 or 1293; the Dondolo in 1307; the Grausoni (or Grasoni) in 1303; the Pantaleo already in the 1270s; the Pollini in 1348; the Rampani in the 1310s; and Savoner, allegedly in 1321. Sanudo, Le vite, 27, 31, 32, 39, 40, 42; Biblioteca Marciana, It. vn 185 (9008), fols. 4V, llv, 24v, 38r, 40v, 42r; Biblioteca Marciana, It. vii 186 (7654), fols. 48v, 52r.

The houses active in the government before the Serrata are identified in the lists of members of the Greater Council between 1266 and 1297 in Roberto Cessi (ed.), Deliberazioni del Maggior Con- siglio di Veneria, vol. 1 (Bologna, 1950), 269-392. These identifications have been supplemented by the exhaustive researches on the pre-Serrata ruling group in Rösch, Der venezianische Adel.

' Sixteen of the fifty-one were represented among the thirty popolani admitted to the nobility in 1381, as a reward for their contributions to the defence effort during the Genoese siege in the War of Chioggia; the other inductees of 1381 had surnames already identified with the nobility. See Chojnacki, In search of the Venetian patriciate', 57. The noble inductees of 1381 are listed in Raphaynus Caresini, Chronica, ed. Ester Pastorello, Rerum Italicarum Scriptores, new edn, vol. 12, pt 2 (Bologna, 1923), 57.
The Libro d'Oro legislation is in ASV, Died, 'Misti', Reg. 31, fols. 109v—110r, 31 August 1506.

ASV, Avogaria di Comun, 'Nascite-Libro d'Oro', Reg. 51/1. Only 128 of the 146 inscribed houses registered male births between 1506 and 1525, the years covered in this register. However, another fourteen were recorded by Marino Sanudo as extant in 1527; I Diarii di Marin Sanudo (1496-1533), ed. Rinaldo Fulin et al. (Venice, 1879-1903), XLIV, 569-72.
For discussions of these laws, see Lane, 'The enlargement of the Great Council', 252-8; and Rösch, Der venezianische Adel, 172-80.
ASV, Maggior Consiglio, Reg. 21, 'Leona', fols. 127rv (19 February 1401/2), 14lr (20 January 1403/4).
Ibid. Reg. 22, 'Ursa', fol. 88r (5 March 1430).

The attraction of the Barbarella lay in its chance of early entry (at age twenty) to voting membership in the Council. This offered families larger representation in the nobility and gave youths a head start in their political careers. On the significance of the different routes to adult noble status, see Chojnacki, 'Political adulthood'; Law, 'Age qualification'.

An applicant was now obliged to prove to the avogadori that he belonged in the Greater Coun- cil, was born legitimately and had reached age twenty-five; ASV, Maggior Consiglio, Reg. 22, 'Ursa', fol. 88r. The fine levied on applicants who were found to lack the hereditary qualification was raised in 1408 from 300 to 500 lire: another indication of increased watchfulness over the boundaries of the nobility. Ibid. Reg. 21, 'Leona', fol. 181v (27 December 1408).

ASV, Avogaria di Comun, 'Prove di Età', Reg. 177. The first entry in this register is dated 2 March 1430, a prompt retroactive response to the enabling legislation of 5 March. Proofs of requisite age for office-holders were also recorded in these registers.

'Debeant videre et sibi legi facere omnes illos qui se scribi fecerent ad XL pro possendo esse de Maiori Consilio, et si eis vel maioriparti eorum videbitur dubium de aliquo ibiscripto, teneantur per sacramentum diligenter inquirere et examinare... veritatem, si ille de quo dubitaverint poterit esse di Maiori Consilio vel non' ('[The avogadori] are to note all who register with the Quarantia for ad- mission to the Greater Council; and if at least two of them have doubts about any registrant, they are to investigate carefully to discover whether he is qualified or not'); emphasis added. This law was passed by the Greater Council on 25 November 1319 and added to the capitulary of the avogadori di comun; see ASV, Avogaria di Comun, 'Capitolare', Reg. 2, cap. 220, fol. 68™. The law of 16 September 1323 which made explicit the requirement that candidates for membership in the Greater Council demonstrate their descent from former members before the doge and his executive council (Collegio) also endowed the avogadori with investigatory discretion: 'si vider et ur eis aliqua obscuritas, quod ipsi possint et teneantur facere suum officium secundum formam sui capitularis et consilii antedicti' ('if they perceive any uncertainty, they are to discharge their duty as indicated in their capitulary and in the aforesaid act [i.e. that of 1319]'); emphasis added; ibid. cap. 221, fol. 68v.

Crouzet Pavan has found evidence of an attentuation of lineage ties in the Quattrocento. Although individual noble lineages remained localized within individual parishes (contracte), pro- perty divisions among brothers and the restitution of the dowries of in-marrying widows frag- mentized the holdings in real property that formerly had given residential concreteness to lineage solidarity. Symbolic bonds persisted, however, not only within lineages but even within the noble casa, dispersed (in contrast with the elites of other Italian cities) throughout the city; Crouzet Pavan, Espaces, pouvoir et société, I, 435-62.
See Donati, L'idea di nobiltà, 15, 22 n. 24.

'Quod pro servando in hoc facto illam honestatem et ilium modum, quod habeat servire inten- tionem terre quam equalius fieri potest, et pro non ponendo divisionem inter nobiles venetiarum: Vadit pars...' ASV, Maggior Consiglio, Reg. 21, 'Leona', fol. 169r (5 July 1407). This measure added the avogadori di comun to the body consisting of the doge, his ducal council and the three capi of the judicial council of the Quarantia. It was rescinded eleven months later; ibid. fol. 176r (10 June 1408).
On the linguistic dimensions of changes in identity, see Scott, '"Experience"', 34.

For these terms, see Jürgen Habermas, The Structural Transformation of the Public Sphere: An Inquiry into a Category of Bourgeois Society, trans. Thomas Burger and Frederick Lawrence (Cambridge, Mass., 1991), esp. pp. 27-31. The chronological specificity of Habermas's application of them is broadened in Roger Chartier, 'Figures of modernity: introduction', in A History of Private Life, vol. in, Passions of the Renaissance, ed. Roger Chartier, trans. Arthur Goldhammer (Cam- bridge, Mass., 1989), 15-19. See also Dena Goodman, 'Public sphere and private life: toward a syn- thesis of current historiographie al approaches to the Old Regime', Hist Theory, 31 (1992), 1-20.

ASV, Senato, 'Misti', Reg. 53, fol. 70rv. The preamble is printed in Giulio Bistort, Il magistrato alle Pompe nella Repubblica di Venezia (Venice, 1912; repr. Bologna, 1969), 107. For fuller discus- sion of this act, see Stanley Chojnacki, 'Marriage legislation and patrician society in fifteenth-century Venice', in Law, Custom, and the Social Fabric in Medieval Europe: Essays in Honor of Bryce Lyon, ed. Bernard S. Bachrach and David Nicholas (Kalamazoo, Mich., 1990), 163-84.

'Inter cives nostros pessima consuetudo orta sit' ('The wicked custom has arisen among our citizenry ); but 'non est possibile quod multi nobiles nostri possint eorum filias maritare' ('it is im- possible for many of our nobles to arrange marriages for their daughters'); Senato, 'Misti', Reg. 53, fol. 70r (emphasis added). On the order of cittadini, see Stephen R. Ell, 'Citizenship and immigra- tion in Venice, 1305 to 1500', PhD diss. (University of Chicago, 1976); and Andrea Zannini, Burocrazia e burocrati a Venezia in eta moderna: i cittadini originari (sec. XVI-XVIII) (Venice, 1993), esp. pp. 11-60.

'Divitum substantia attenuatur in maximum damnum et preiuditium suorum heredum... ali- qui eorum filias coguntur in monasteriis carcerare, cum dignis lacrimis et plantibus ipsarum, aliqui tenent ipsas innuptas, cum rubore et periculo...' ('Their wealth is reduced, gravely harming their heirs... some fathers are forced to imprison their daughters in convents, amid justifiable tears and wailing, others keep them as spinsters, risking dishonour'). Senato, 'Misti', Reg. 53, fol. 70r.
Ibid. The amendment reaffirmed that the daughters of 'omnium civium' - referring to both nobles and cittadini - must observe the 1,600 ducat limit.

The proponent of the repeal measure, Leonardo Emo, asserted that the dowry limitation law had produced 'diminutione honoris et libertatis huius civitatis' ('a reduction of the honour and liberty of this city') because all Venetians were now 'de sua libertate privatos' ('deprived of their freedom'). He urged repeal in order that 'omnes cives et fideles nostri' ('all citizens and loyal subjects') might be restored to 'sua solita libertate in facta nuptiarum et dotium' ('their customary freedom in matters regarding marriage and dowries'). ASV, Senato, 'Misti', Reg. 53, fol. 94v (30 December 1420). The repeal attempt was defeated by 73 nay votes against 45 yeas, with 8 absten- sions. The act threatening a fine of 1000 ducats for proponents or supportors of further repeal efforts was passed immediately after the defeat of the repeal proposal.
ASV, Maggior Consiglio, Reg. 22, 'Ursa', fols. 47v-48r (26 May 1422). On this act see Chojnacki, 'Marriage legislation'.

The surnames of mothers of Barbarella candidates were likewise not recorded in registration records until 1431; ASV, Avogaria di Comun, 'Balla d'Oro', Reg. 162, passim. It thus appears that the determination to record maternal identity did not become effective until after passage of the 1430 measure applying strict credentials tests to men who bypassed the Barbarella.

In the useful formulation of Paul Ricoeur, the second Serrata framed a new collective noble identity consisting of an idem component, whereby older and newer noble houses were assimilated by means of the procedural measures that they now all were obliged to undergo; and an ipse compo- nent, in which their separateness from the popolo was underscored; Ricoeur, Oneself as Another, 3.

In addition to the law of 1420 which permitted daughters of popolani but not those of cittadini to exceed the 1,600 ducat dowry limit when marrying nobles, another statute, of 1407, granted citizenship privileges within Venice to any foreigner who settled in in the city and 'took as wife a resi- dent of Venice'. Ell, 'Citizenship and immigration in Venice', 125-7; the act of 1407 is reproduced in full on p. 233. On the 'hierarchization' of society in the late Trecento and Quattrocento, cf. Dennis Romano, Patricians and Popolani: The Social Foundations of the Venetian Renaissance State (Baltimore, Md, 1987), 152-8; Zannini, Burocrazia e burocrati, 34-40.

Already in the 1420s nobilis juvenis was routinely applied to youths registering for the Bar- barella; see ASV, Avogaria di Comun, 'Balla d'Oro', Reg. 162, passim. Nobilis mulier became stan- dard later. In 1429 and 1430, noble widows filing for recovery of their dowries were normally given the title honesta mulier by court scribes; by the 1460s the title normally attributed had become nobilis domina or nobilis mulier. Compare ASV, Giudici del Proprio, 'Vadimoni', Reg. 1 (1429-33), fols. 3r, 6V, etc., with ibid. Reg. 4 (1457-65), fols. 41v, 58v, 64v, etc.

On liminality as providing a focus for collective identity, see Norton, Reflections on Political Identity, 53. On the liminal stage among noble youths in Venice, see Chojnacki, 'Political adulthood', 800ff.

For example, a sumptuary law of 146S addressing excessive expenditure on dress by women im- posed a fine on the 'husbands, fathers, or others with authority over the offending women [maritis, sive patribus, vel illis sub quorum potestate contrafacientes mulieres essent]'; ASV, Senato, 'Terra', Reg. 5, fol. 46r. Another law, of 1443, authorized fines and the loss of office-holding privileges for fathers whose sons misbehaved during meetings of the Greater Council; ASV, Maeeior Consielio, Reg. 22,'Ursa', fol. 148v

Francesco Barbara, De re uxoria, ed. Attilio Gnesotto (Padua, 1915). There is a translation of the preface and book 2, with introduction, in B. G. Kohl and R. G. Witt (eds.), The Earthly Republic (Philadelphia, Pa, 1978), 179-208. On the significance of Barbara's work for patrician culture, see Margaret L. King, 'Caldiera and the Barbaras on marriage and the family', Journal of Mediev R, 6 (1976), 19-50, at pp. 31-5; idem, Venetian Humanism in an Age of Patrician Dominance (Princeton, N.J., 1985), 92-8.

The phrase 'reinforcement of patriarchy' was first used as a chapter heading in Lawrence Stone, The Family, Sex, and Marriage in England 1550-1800 (London, 1977). The location in the Renaissance of a strengthening of male prerogatives and a consequent deterioration in the position of women received a formulation that has become canonical in the germinal essay of Joan Kelly, 'Did women have a Renaissance?', in Becoming Visible: Women in European History, ed. Renate Briden- thal and Claudia Koonz (Boston, Mass., 1977), 137-64.
Giddens, Central Problems in Social Theory, 5, 72-73.

On the lineage implications of dowry restitution, see Crouzet Pavan, Espace, pouvoir et société, 448-58; and Stanley Chojnacki, 'The power of love: wives and husbands in late medieval Venice', in Women and Power in the Middle Ages, ed. Mary Erler and Maryanne Kowaleski (Athens, Ga, 1988), 126-48. For the relationship between dowry, corredo and marriage strategies outside Venice, see Anna Caso, 'Per la storia délia società milanese: i corredi nuziali nell'ultima età viscontea e nel periodo della repubblica ambrosiana (1433-1450), dagli atti del notaio Protaso Sansoni', Nuov Riv St, 65 (1981), 521-51; Christiane Klapisch-Zuber, 'Les corbeilles de la mariée', in La maison et le nom: stratégies et rituels dans l'Italie de la Renaissance (Paris, 1990), 215-27; Julius Kirshner, 'Materials for a gilded cage: non-dotal assets in Florence, 1300-1500', in The Family in Italy from Antiquity to the Present, ed. David I. Kertzer and Richard P. Sailer (New Haven, Conn, and London, 1991), 184-207.

ASV, Giudici del Proprio, 'Vadimoni', Reg. 4, fol. 32r (marriage contract of 1430); ibid. Reg. 5, fol. llr (contract of 1428); Giudici del Esaminador, 'Vendizioni', Reg. 7, fol. 15v (contract of 1435).

'Appresso promette el dicto ser Vetor Trun de far carta de dota hover impromessa a la dicta dona de ducati mille sexanta sie e do terzi chomo vuol la leze. E lo resto fina a la summa de ducati mille e siecento che son ducati zinquecento e trentatre e uno terzo sia liberamente dadi et donadi al dicto ser Vetor Trun per doni e choriedi delà dicta dona.' ASV, Giudici del Proprio, 'Vadimoni', Reg. 4, fol. 2V.

ASV, Giudici del Proprio, 'De giudicatu', Regs. 1 and 2. The acts involved the dowries of wives or daughters of nobles, including some who married popolani. The two registers record the cases of 135 such women, but in only 122 can the dowry amounts be ascertained.

In a will of 1335, Piero Morosini bequeathed to each of his daughters 1,000 lire ad grossos (roughly 385 ducats) for her dowry and corredo, 'secundum usum nobilium dominarum de Veneciis' ('as is customary for noble women in Venice'); ASV, Notarile, 'Testamenti', Busta 1154, Bruto, no. 32. In a civil action of 1382, the Giudici del Procurator ordered that the estate of Federico Corner should add to his dowry allocation to his daughters 'quid deffecerit congruentie' ('what it lacks to make it suitable') in order to carry out Federico's testamentary provision that the daughters receive 'quelo che besogna per maridarle' ('what is necessary for their marriages'); ASV, Giudici del Pro- curator, 'Sentenze a Legge', Reg. 2, fol. 114". In 1385 Nicolô Morosini ordered in his will that if his descendants should lack the means of providing dowries for their daughters, then his bequest to them in immovables might be sold to 'maridarle segondo la condicion soa' ('arrange marriages appropriate to their status'); Notarile, 'Testamenti', Busta 679, Bellancini, prot., fol. 26v. In his will of 1416 Giovanni Morosini instructed his brothers to add enough from his estate to their father's bequest of 1,400 ducats for the marriage of their sister 'ut ipsa cum honore et prout congruit conditionem domus mee honorificentius maritetur' ('in order that she may marry as honorably as possible and in a manner befitting the status of my house'); ibid. Busta 1234, Sorio, no. 509. Fathers also specified that they wanted their daughters to marry noble husbands; Andrea Ari- mondo in 1427 declared that each of his daughters was to be married 'in uno zentilomo de Veniesia' ('to a Venetian gentleman') (ASV, Cancelleria Inferiore, 'Miscellanea Testamenti', Notai Diversi, Busta 27, no. 2697); that same year Michele Navagero instructed his executors that his daughter 'se debia maridar in zentil homo' ('should marry a gentleman') (ASV, Notarile, 'Testamenti', Busta 1157, Croci, prot. Il, fol. 14r). In the Quattrocento, zentilomo was the usual vernacular term for patrician (nobilis vir in Latin).

In a will of 1476 Marino Pisani bequeathed his daughter, Pisana, 3,500 ducats 'pro eius docte et coredis' ('for her dowry and corredo'); ASV, Notarile, Testamenti, Busta 727, Moisis, no. 1. In 1485 Alvise Zane allocated at least 3,500 ducats for the marriage portion of his daughter, Michela; ibid. Busta 68, Bonicardi, no. 316.

In a will of 1437 Giovanni Morosini noted 'con amaretudine non so che lasar' ('it fills me with bitterness that I don't know what to bequeath') to his daughter, Marietta, because his estate 'no sera sufficiente a maridarla dagandola tutto' ('will be insufficient to marry her off even if she gets all of it'); ASV, Notarile, 'Testamenti', Busta 1232, Stefani, no. 314. Eleven years later, Francesco Morosini allocated for his daughter's portion a range from 500 to 1,800 ducats, depending on whether Venice was at war when she came to marriageable age, 'perche i tempi de guera le sera molto piu in frété de danari per pagar faction' ('because in wartime taxes will weigh heavily'); ASV, Procuratori di San Marco, 'Commissarie Miste', Busta 158a, 'Francesco Morosini', parchment dated 5 April 1448.

See Natalie Zemon Davis, 'Boundaries and the sense of self in sixteenth-century France', in Reconstructing Individualism: Autonomy, Individuality, and the Self in Western Thought, ed. Thomas C. Heller et al. (Stanford, Calif., 1986), 53-63.

Only one of 122 sample noble dowries was brought by a noble wife to a non-noble husband, the 400 ducats that Polisena, daughter of 'viri nobilis' Giorgio Capello, recovered from the estate of her husband, Jacopo Caroldo; Giudici del Proprio, 'De Giudicatum', Reg. 1, fol. 2V. It is not known whether this Caroldo was related to Gian Giacomo Caroldo, secretary of the Council of Ten in the early Cinquecento, who wrote a Historia di Venetia, and who was certainly a cittadino; see Antonio Carile, La cronachistica veneziana (secoli XIII-XVI) di fronte alla spartizione della Romania nel 1204 (Florence: Olschki, 1969), 158-9.

On varied access to political office, see Donald Queller, The Venetian Patriciate: Reality versus Myth (Urbana, 111., 1986). On matrimonial difficulties for men, see Stanley Chojnacki, 'Subaltern patriarchs: patrician bachelors in Renaissance Venice', in Medieval Masculinities: Regarding Men in the Middle Ages, ed. Clare A. Lees (Minneapolis, Minn., 1994), 73-90.

A prominent factor in opening the possibilities of individual choice was the influence of mothers, fortified with married women's autonomy in disposing of their wealth. Often endorsed by their husbands but often independently of them, women offered their children the possibility of framing their own social identity without direction from the structures of patriarchal authority, paternal or governmental. On the varieties of adult experience, see Stanley Chojnacki, 'Measuring adulthood: adolescence and gender in Renaissance Venice',/Fam Hist, 17 (1992), 371-95. On the role of mothers in providing opportunities for elective adult vocation for both sons and daughters, see idem, "'The most serious duty": motherhood, gender, and patrician culture in Renaissance Venice', in Refiguring Woman: Gender Studies and the Italian Renaissance, ed. Marilyn Migiel and Juliana Schiesari (Ithaca, N.Y., 1990), 133-54.

Cf. Scott, "'Experience'", 34: '[Subjects] are not unified, autonomous individuals exercising free will, but rather subjects whose agency is created through situations and statuses conferred on them.'
